[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 23, 41, 42, 56] [Staking System] The governance, stake_pool, staking_contract, and vesting modules are all publicly exposed - can these be combined to exploit staking reward calculations or bypass lock-up periods? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 49] [Utility Coin] The utility_coin module (also re-exported globally) is public - does this test utility for coin operations have proper guards against production use where it could enable unauthorized minting? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 21] [Fee Mechanism] The fee_statement module is exposed - can external code manipulate fee calculations or create transactions with incorrect fee statements? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 8-9] [Account Access] The account_address and account_config modules are public - can these be used to generate privileged system addresses or bypass account initialization checks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 33] [Object Security] The object_address module is exposed - could this be exploited to predict object addresses and front-run object creation transactions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 7] [Access Path Security] The access_path module is public - can malicious code construct access paths that reach restricted state or bypass Move module boundaries? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 31] [Network Address] The network_address module is exposed - can attackers forge network addresses to impersonate validators or manipulate peer discovery? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 27] [Mempool Security] The mempool_status module is public - does this expose mempool internal state that could be used for transaction censorship or front-running attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 72] [VM Types] The vm module is exposed - can external code access VM internal types to construct malformed execution contexts or bypass gas metering? (Critical)
[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 57] [VM Status] The vm_status module is public - could this be exploited to forge successful execution status for transactions that actually failed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 20] [Executable Module] The executable module is exposed - does this allow external code to construct executable bytecode that bypasses verification? (Critical)
[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 65] [Block Executor] The block_executor module is public - can this be misused to execute blocks outside the consensus-driven execution pipeline? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 28-30] [Move Type Safety] The move_any, move_fixed_point, and move_utils modules are exposed - could these Move language utilities be exploited to bypass Move's type safety or resource constraints? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 22] [Function Info Security] The function_info module is public - can this be used to leak information about private Move functions or manipulate function dispatch? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 14, 19] [Event System] Both contract_event and event modules are exposed - can malicious code emit fake events that mislead off-chain indexers or applications? (Medium)
[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 24] [Indexer Security] The indexer module is public - does this expose data structures that could be manipulated to cause indexing inconsistencies? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 50-52] [Validator Configuration] The validator_config, validator_info, and validator_performances modules are all public - can these be combined to manipulate validator reputation or election probabilities? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 52] [Performance Manipulation] The validator_performances module is exposed - could Byzantine validators forge performance metrics to avoid being ejected from the active set? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Line: 25] [JWKS Security] The jwks (JSON Web Key Set) module is public - can this be exploited to forge authentication tokens or bypass keyless account validation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 13, 46] [Timestamp Security] The chain_id and timestamp modules are exposed - can these be manipulated to cause time-based vulnerabilities or chain ID confusion attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/lib.rs] [Lines: 18, 32, 40, 43, 66] [Helper Modules] Multiple helper/utility modules (error, nibble, serde_helper, state_proof, bytes) are public - do any of these expose low-level primitives that should be restricted? (Low)
